comments.author: kalel Wilson

comments.text:
+givemeajackson The 911 has had the same shape for 40+ years, but it 
doesn't look the same. Nor does Porsche have several models that are 
exactly alike. Ferdinand Porsche said, "Change is easy. Improvement is far 
more difficult." The 911/Porsche proves itself and its strategy through 
sales, can't say the same for Aston Martin. Aston has the same old and 
rather weak V12, an ancient gearbox, a dated interior, quality control 
issues with stitching and materials, its not very light on it's feet 
despite being the smallest aston, it's much slower around a track than a 
car that has 100 less HP, and it's design, though good looking, is old...
I may be beating up on Aston Martin, but i really like them and want to see 
them be competitive. I wanna see them go toe to toe with ferrari and the 
F12, but they currently cannot get anywhere close.

comments.author: Sarin Murlidar

captions.text:
There are few things more evocative than a
V12 sports car, and they are becoming rarer

and rarer. Fortunately, Aston Martin have
stayed true to their heritage and still makes
12-cylinder sports cars.

The most extreme of which is this car, the
V12 Vantage S, now fitted with the Sportshift

gearbox and adaptive damping for the first
time. The engine's been tuned as well- and
it's the fastest production car they make.

How will it fare against arguably the most
focused track-based sports car money can buy:
Porsche's 911 GT3?

To find out we've brought the new 991 GT3
to take on the brutish British Aston Martin
in an Auto Express track battle.

Now into its 3rd generation ever since its
launch in 1999, the GT3 has been the benchmark

for handling precision. The new 991 generation
has 469bhp and 440Nm or torque from its 3.8-litre

flat-six engine. For the first time it comes
equipped with a PDK dual-clutch gearbox.

The Aston Martin V12 Vantage S squeezes Aston's
biggest engine into their smallest and most

focused sports car. With 565bhp and 620 Nm
of torque, the V12 produces more power than

the Porsche, but the Aston weighs 235kg more
than the lightweight 911 - and for the first

time, the V12 comes equipped with Aston's
Sportshift automated manual gearbox.

Ok, we'll start with the Aston Martin. Now
the V12 Vantage is track-proven, like the

GT3, this V12 Vantage has taken part in the
Nurburgring 24h, so this car has got a track

pedigree and it's been revised now so it's
got the Sportshift gearbox for the first time,

it's got adaptive damping and the engine's
been modified so the torque is lower down
in the engine.

There's no mistaking when you get in this
car straight away that it's a V12. As soon

as you get on the throttle you've got that
unique V12 sound.

The track's pretty wet, it's been raining
all day. It's very low grip, hardly any temperature.

You've got to be very very smooth with the
throttle and you're always managing oversteer

in the Aston. If you're too aggressive on
the throttle, lot of wheelspin. You can't

just stand on the throttle out of the corners,
you've got to be very progressive as you get

into the power. The toque comes in quite early
as well so you've got to be reasonably careful.

Like all Astons it's got a really nice front-end.
Very positive on the front-end.The problem

is, this car just feels a little bit soft
at the rear-end. Even with adaptive damping

you don't sense that the rear-end is that
well tied down. You feel like there's a lot

of roll over the rear axle and it doesn't
give you a great sense of confidence when
you're sliding or on the power.

There you can feel the wheelspin. The car
is pretty playful, though, so again with that

sort of well-sorted front-end you can balance
the car into aggressive slides like that.

I'm just trying to get some heat into the
tyres.You can play around and get it sliding.It's

a proper muscle car and you can really get
it sliding and playing around.

It's quite tricky today as the grip level's
changing metre by metre, with dry patches

and wet patches so it's going to be quite
interesting to see how we get on when it comes
to getting a lap time in the Aston.

We come round now after that first lap...smooth
it out now and try our flying lap.

Starting in second gear into the last corner,
going to kick some grip across the line here

as we come up now to start the lap. Across
the line, down to second here. About 90 on
the approach.

Squirming on the brakes as we come into the
corner. Again through these changes of direction

you can feel the slight sogginess in the rear
while the car's just rolling around the rear

axle. Trying to manage the oversteer as I
get on the power.

The biggest problem is this Sportshift gearbox
- it's really quite slow and there's quite

a hesitation as you shift up a gear. You can
try to manage it by putting a slight lift

into the throttle each time you shift but
you don't really want to have to, it's not

as good as more modern systems in other cars.
It's quite slow and a little bit antiquated.

Hard on the brakes, squirming on the brakes,
getting a little bit of oversteer on the way

in, managing the oversteer on the way out.
Bit of a slide, up a gear.

Just trying to keep the car fairly balanced
again, managing that oversteer on the slippery

surface. The gears just a bit slow there on
the exit. High speed change of direction here,

you can feel it working its front tyres quite
hard but it's very positive on the front end.

Down into second... trying not to do too much
oversteer, too much there to be honest. Trying

to keep it smooth. Bit of wheelspin and accelerate
across the line.

So in wet, tricky conditions, the Aston Martin
did a lap time of 1.15.07 seconds. Can the
Porsche be any faster?

Let's see how the GT3 compares. Thanks to
the success of all the previous generations

of GT3, there's a massive weight of expectation
about this car. It's a big step, the 991 GT3,

the first thing is we've got a PDK gearbox
- no manual option - and the classic Metzger

engine has been replaced by a more modern
engine. But any doubts that the engine would

be a disappointment are absolutely blown out
of the water the second you brake for the
first time in this car.

It revs to 9,000rpm, builds from 3,500rpm
onwards. Just a massive crescendo of power

all the way up to 9,000. With the track being
so damp I've really got to be careful as I

bite on the power but just listen to that
noise as you accelerate up to 9,000rpm.

It feels quicker in a straight line than the
Aston initially. It's got quite an aggressive

pilotsport tyre so you can feel the wheelspin
and the snap oversteer there as I light up

the rear wheels in these damp conditions.
It takes a bit of respect, this car.

I've got all the stability controls turned
off. The PDK is in its sportiest setting.

Unlike other 911s the good thing is that the
PDK won't kick down so like here in this corner

we can be in 3rd gear and wait wait wait,
feed the power in and it won't kick down a

gear.You're in full control of the PDK which
is great.The shifts are so much faster than

the Aston. Really really crisp upshift, beautiful
brutal downshift.

I've got a bit of heat into the tyres and
I come round and try a flying lap in the 911

and see how we're getting on. The track feels
really greasy, a lot of big puddles.

Coming into the last corner, second gear,
listen to that engine, 9,000rpm, 79mph as

we go for 2nd and 3rd. You can feel the vibration
as the front tyres start to scrabble for grip,

but the change of direction is amazing, brilliant
body control.

Really stiff and the brutal upshift, 4th gear,
missing the puddle here in the braking zone,

hard on the brakes. Brakes are amazing, bit
of ABS coming in there. Getting the wipers

on got a big puddle there. Battling the understeer
there, lighting the rears up over the puddle.

Up to 4th gear hard on the brakes, ABS kicking
in, squirming a bit, lots of patchy wet bits,

bit of oversteer on the exit. Just troubled
the braking a bit there which is why, you

know as a 911 you've got that weight to the
rear you will get punished on the way into
a corner.

Lost a little bit of time there but traction
is pretty impressive once you've got the car

out of the standing water. Change of direction
through there is amazing.Hard on the brakes

to the last corner. Second gear, the turning
in this GT3 is absolutely staggering.

Managing the wheelspin on the exit back to
2nd, trying to keep it clean, 3rd gear, across
the line.

With soaking wet tarmac and near-freezing
temperatures these sports cars have faced

the toughest of challenges today - but which
one comes out on top?

Well, the new 911 GT3 has exceeded our expectations.
The engine is astonishing, the chassis is

equally capable and the PDK gearbox has been
improved and it's perfectly suited to this
type of car.

The Aston is great too - the V12 engine is
packed with character and it has a playful

chassis. There's no doubting how stunning
it looks, but against the stopwatch in wet

conditions, the Porsche was 1.5 seconds a
lap quicker and in our dry practice laps it

was a full 4 seconds faster than the Aston
Martin.

There really isn't any loser here.We're glad
that both of these sports cars exist and it's
been a privilege to drive them.

If you liked this film, click on the video
windows to watch our Porsche 911 Turbo S track

title: Porsche 911 GT3 vs Aston Martin V12 Vantage S on track
